message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a deletion in chromosome 22. Among the options, only an aplastic thymus is associated with DiGeorge syndrome. This results in T cell deficiency which makes patients more susceptible to infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and diagnostic findings suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by deletion of the 22q11.2 region. This syndrome causes thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, which ultimately leads to immunodeficiency. Therefore, the most likely finding on autopsy would be an aplastic thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination are indicative of DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a deletion on chromosome 22q11.2. The most common finding on autopsy in affected individuals is aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles is a finding in autoimmune diseases affecting the thymus. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes can be seen in patients with severe combined immunodeficiency. Accessory spleens are a common finding in the general population and are not specific to any disease process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, as well as the FISH analysis indicating 22q11.2 deletion, suggest a diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Aplastic thymus is a common finding in DiGeorge syndrome due to the failure of development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, which leads to a lack of T lymphocytes. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles is associated with autoimmune conditions such as autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes are seen in patients with X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome. Accessory spleen is a benign anomaly that is detected in approximately 10% of autopsies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a microdeletion on chromosome 22. Aplastic thymus is a common finding in these patients and can lead to severe T-cell deficiency and recurrent infections. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles is seen in the thymus in some autoimmune diseases. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes may be seen in certain primary immunodeficiency disorders. Accessory spleen is a normal anatomical variant and is not related to DiGeorge syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a 22q11.2 deletion. Aplastic thymus is a characteristic finding in this condition, and can lead to T-cell deficiency and susceptibility to infections. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles can be seen in the thymus in normal development, but not in DiGeorge syndrome. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes and accessory spleen are not specifically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of physical exam findings, recurrent respiratory infections, and hypocalcemia suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by 22q11.2 deletion. One of the features of this syndrome is aplastic thymus, which would be the most likely finding on autopsy. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles is seen in autoimmune diseases affecting the thymus. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes may be seen in HIV infection or lymphoma. Accessory spleen is a benign anomaly that is not associated with this syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a 22q11.2 deletion, which is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which is characterized by hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands, among other findings. Therefore, the most likely finding on autopsy is an aplastic thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation and 22q11.2 deletion suggest DiGeorge syndrome, which is characterized by aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus gland. Therefore, the most likely finding on autopsy would be an aplastic thymus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest the presence of DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a 22q11.2 deletion. The diagnosis is confirmed by FISH analysis. DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, which leads to T-cell deficiency, as well as cardiac abnormalities and craniofacial anomalies. Therefore, the most likely finding on autopsy would be an aplastic thymus. Hypertrophy of Hassall's corpuscles would be seen in chronic autoimmune diseases. Absent follicles in the lymph nodes would suggest a lymphoproliferative disorder. Accessory spleen would be a normal variant finding on autopsy.
